Long bond rates would be much higher than 2% if the market believed we're on the brink of sustained inflation, as we were in the 1970s.  I remember the 70s, and for sure there are similarities.  "What we’re experiencing now is a lot more like 1947 than like 1979," wrote economist Paul Krugman a couple of days ago.  See https://www.nytimes.com/2021/11/11/opinion/inflation-history.html.  " ... the bond market is, in effect, predicting a temporary bump in inflation, not a permanent rise."  So extreme monetary policy, i.e., quantitative easing, can end without pushing up 30-year rates.  But we are very near the boundary between bins 2 and 3, and a good argument can be made for either one.  The crowd is at 50/50, which seems about right.
Stochastic simulation for 36 days and magical thinking for 2 minutes
Adjusting buckets based on aggregation of 1) random walk 4CAST, 2) Winter's 4Cast, 3) Selected Crowd 4Cast; using current 1.91 yield.

Well that was a terrible auction today. 30 year jumped 6 basis pts.  Dealers got stuck with alot.  
Too much uncertainty or just two big possibilities that is either inflation will continue to surge and Fed needs to rapidly end taper or inflation is temporary and will settle for over next 3 months and so Fed cannot taper too quickly.  Arguments are strong for either outcome and since this the start of a new phase data is short. This is one of those times when you need to position for either event.

Interest rates largely turn on inflation expectations.  We were fearing cost-push inflation due to supply chain problems and Americans delaying returning to work.   The primary factors driving the inflation narrative have improved.  The employment numbers are now better.  This includes the upward revisions to the past numbers.   Pfizer also has a new very effective covid pill. Oil prices are heading the other direction however.  Oil demand is increasing as the pandemic plateaus or declines.  Yet, supply is determined by OPEC+ politics.  The Saudis and Russians are working together to limit supply and raise prices to a reported $100 a barrel by Christmas.  This will have an impact. Also, the end date for this question is less than two months away.  The public tends to greatly over-react to strong positive and negative news stories.  Also, reflexivity is definitely at play per Soros.  There were a lot of negative stories on inflation.  Yet, the stories improved just this week with the employment and Pfizer news.  The news on oil prices has been and is still very negative.  I think the over-all news on employment will improve over the next two months, but oil news will get worse.    Therefore,  balancing the major influences -- the employment numbers,  the Pfizer pills, the pre-pandemic normal rate, the return to normal, oil prices and media reports--the net is a strong upward pressure to a pre-pandemic normal (3.0-3.5 percent).   The only question is how long it will take.   We are about 50 days away from the end date and today's number is 1.887% on a strong downward trend (over-reaction to the recent good news?) so I am estimating 45-55.
Closing in on the end of the year so I'm narrowing around 2%.
I think i got it now?
recent wage hike, low jobless claims

The economy only grew at two percent in the third quarter.  This was far below the 2.8 percent predicted.   The current rate is approximately 1.983.  There is not much reason to believe the 30-year rate will rise to 2.5 percent or below 1.5 percent in just two months.  The news would have to be sudden and very inciteful to investors for this to occur.  So, I suspect a range of 1.5- to 2.5-percent is probably a 90 percent confidence interval for the next two months.   My best guest the number will increase a bit as the latest covid bubble continues downward and the economy picks up a bit.

Inflation may go higher, and may last longer without increasing interest rate, due to ongoing supply issues, and increased demand caused by higher savings. But inflation trend likely won't become very obvious yet at 31 Dec.

But there is the thought that this latest rise is the Bond market pricing in the announcement of the Fed ending QE in November.  Because of this for the last ten weeks i expect the yield to trend  to 2.2. I am leaving 15% in the 1.5 to 2.0 bin because if the Fed does not announce an end to QE in November the rate will drop.

The big debate among economists and financial analysts concerns whether inflation is transitory or not.  The long bond interest rate should reflect the answer to the question.  The 30-year US Treasury rate has been in a narrow range since early July, ending today at 1.946%.  It seems just as likely to go up from here as to go down.  But with 14 weeks remaining I will bet against a move of >0.5%.

Changing forecast drastically. I overestimated the link between current inflation and the 30 yr yield. There obviously IS a relationship, but a much less significant one than I first thought. There is a lot of evidence showing significant inflation but this has not correlated with a rise in yield.

I will continue to watch the rate. But i would expect a more strong increase in rate to sustain my belief in a rate abkvw 2.5 by december. This meandering around suggests weakness to me.

See https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-treasury-securities/foreign-holdings-of-treasuries-rise-in-january-as-yield-rise-lures-investors-u-s-data-idUSKBN2B72O5. And pension funds provide another source of buying, since they require guaranteed sources of income.  Maybe we've seen the peak in long-term bond rates.  That's not what I was forecasting, so it's time to revise.

The yield is rising and the Fed is reluctant to do anything about the long of the yield curve. As of today UST 30yr trades at 2.27%.

Why is it so low?  Historically this is a very low 30 year treasury yield, caused by persistently low-interest rates and a lack of inflation over the past few decades.
https://www.macrotrends.net/2521/30-year-treasury-bond-rate-yield-chart
https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/data-chart-center/interest-rates/pages/TextView.aspx?data=yieldAll Why is it rising? Less people wanting to buy a 30 year bond = a lower price = higher yield. I think demand is decreasing because of recent inflationary expectations. More and more people are expecting the inflation rate to be higher than the current bond yield. This situation means they would be losing money (eg. 2.3% bond yield but 3% inflation = real loss of 0.7%), so they obviously don't want to buy any. Inflation is not caused by more money sitting around, it's caused by the spending of that money (velocity of money). More spending = increased velocity = more inflation (if other conditions stay the same). I think inflationary expectations & actual inflation will only get higher in the coming months. There is an unprecedented amount of private savings right now (More than $2 trillion! [1]). As the economy starts to open up, more of this money will be spent. The unemployment rate will gradually decrease, again causing more spending. And, there is likely going to be a HUGE stimulus package of more than $1.5 trillion, which will cause more spending. Furthermore, There may be another huge spending package, focusing on industry, again totalling more than $1 trillion.  And, on top of all that, the Fed just said they would not attempt to slow down inflation for some time. They are not going to raise the interest rates, and want inflation to exceed the 2% target to 'make up for lost ground' over the previous decade.

Commodity and house prices are already rising very quickly.  However, a slow jobs recovery could prevent inflation from gaining momentum for a few years. Also, a rising yield becomes more attractive, meaning more people will want to buy it, meaning the yield will get pushed back down in the short term (more attractive to the ones with lower inflation expectations). Furthermore, a sudden change in Fed policy is unlikely but still possible.  [1] https://www.statista.com/statistics/246268/personal-savings-rate-in-the-united-states-by-month/#:~:text=of%20the%20Treasury.-,The%20personal%20saving%20rate%20in%20the%20United%20States%20amounted%20to,trillion%20U.S.%20dollars%20in%202020.

If one looks at the graph of the 30 UST yield from 2000 until today then one can draw a fairly neat downward sloping trend channel (upper boundary: connect the 2000 high at 6.70% with the 2011 high at 4.75%; lower boundary: connect the 2003 low at 4.16% with the 2012 low at 2.55). The only time 30yr UST was out of this channel was in the stress of 2008. Therefore based on this trend channel it is unlikely that 30yr UST should be below 0.85% and above 2.90% in the course of 2021. Considering that the current trend in the yield is upwards, the most likely scenario is that it will be between 1.5% and 3%.

There's a debate of whether it's too much and if it's larger than the output gap, and my understanding is the latest bump is people pricing in his stimulus. I would guess once it passes the yield goes up a little more and then I'm guessing not too much change over the next year. Based on that I'm switching 2-2.5 to be most likely and increasing the likelihood of 2.5 to 3.

The Conference Board's base forecast is 4.1% GDP growth in 2021, and their upside forecast is 6.4% growth.  See https://www.conference-board.org/research/us-forecast Forecasts can be wrong, but IMHO this one seems reasonable.  Higher levels of fiscal stimulus became more likely with the two GA senate races going D.  And widespread COVID immunity should prevail by the second half of the year.  So I will bet on a stronger economy and an increase in the long bond rate by year end. Normally the Federal Reserve only controls short-term interest rates, letting the market set the long-term rate.  These are not normal times.  My forecast could go wrong if the Fed exerts "yield curve control," buying long bonds to hold down yields. Here is an explanation of Yield Curve Control (YCC) by the Saint Louis Federal Reserve -- https://www.stlouisfed.org/on-the-economy/2020/august/what-yield-curve-control This Bloomberg article is a bit old (Dec 7, 2020), but it outlines some possibilities for Fed intervention in long-term interest rates.  See https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2020-12-07/will-1-10-year-treasury-yield-force-the-fed-into-curve-control?sref=x7nYEkiY The 30-year bond began 2020 at about 2.25%; it's now 1.84%.  At what point and to what extend will the Fed act to hold down long bond rates?  I don't know, but my bet is that the Fed won't interfere until the long rate exceeds at least 2.5%, and maybe 3% or bit higher.

The Fed won't allow yields to go above 2%, even though inflation is already above 2% on a month to month basis. the US government can't afford to pay a higher rate of interest on the national debt. https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/democrats-will-force-fed-yield-curve-control

Fed likely to keep yields capped - Will likely tweak forward guidance around asset purchases

Likely to remain low, but I think it will recover some or at least hold fairly steady over the course of the year, particularly with more COVID relief being passed, and I think a 3rd COVID relief package could be possible a few months from now as well. Factors which may influence the rate (see linked article for source at end) according to my understanding (which may be flawed, some of these are hard to follow): 1.) Economic conditions: Not great, but I don't think things will deteriorate much. Government response has been much stronger than 2009 and has really played an important role in keeping things afloat. Once vaccines hit and the virus plays a smaller role I think there's a good chance for a faster recovery. This points toward steady or increasing yields in my view.
2.) Demand for risk-free securities: Demand drives yields down, and in uncertain economic conditions like now (despite a strong stock market) I think that's playing a role in lowering yields. I'm unsure on this factor, the S&P 500 seems inflated relative to the economy and a correction could cause treasury yields to drop as people switch from stocks to bonds. But a correction may not happen.
3.) Supply of T bills: Deficits are large, so the government needs to issue more T bills. This could have an effect on raising the yield, as to get more buyers of T bills the government has to offer more attractive rates.
4.) Monetary policy: I don't understand this fully, but I believe the gist is the FED performs actions that will lower the interest rate to boost investing and economic activity. The FED has committed to low rates for the near future and is actively trying to boost the economy, so this will keep interest rates low. https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/FEDFUNDS
5.) Inflation: High inflation results in higher bond yields as I understand it. More inflation means bonds - which are typically lower yielding - are less desirable, and to attract buyers the bond rates have to go up. Inflation has declined over time, which has probably played a role in declining bond yields. And inflation drops during recessions, likely causing bond yields to drop with them. https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/FPCPITOTLZGUSA Some of these factors counteract the others, but overall I think the economy is likely to hold steady or recover at a decent pace thanks to effective government measures, and I think that will translate to steady or slightly increasing treasury yields. It's also interesting to note that the 2009 recession seemed to create a much briefer drop in yields than this one has. I don't know why that is, but it raises the possibility that the drop in yields could be very temporary this time too. Source for factors: https://www.thebalance.com/historical-u-s-treasury-yield-charts-417126

The 30-year US Treasury yield has been on a precipitous decline since October 1981and the economic impact of COVID will likely push the yield down further.  While the yield has recovered from the March 2020 low of 1.25% to 1.66% on December 28, it seems likely that continued economic stressors from COVID will further depress yields.  Additionally, the Federal Reserve's Quantitative Easing program will also lower yields over the next year.

Fat part of the distribution is definitely the top two options. Given a reasonable amount of probability to the other pieces given a “fat tail” philosophy, but for UST yields I can clearly see the argument for much lower volatility. May tighten up as the year goes on.

Expectation is for the Republicans to keep a narrow majority in the Senate after the Georgia runoff elections. This should limit the upside to government spending for 2021. Will need to re-evaluate if the Democratic nominees sweep and the Senate is split 50/50. This split could bias government spending on infrastructure or clean energy higher if all Democrats support the plan since Harris will have the deciding vote. All else equal, higher government spending should move inflation higher.
Fed policy shifts mid year, 30 bond rates move 6 months in advance of anticipated inflation rate and year-end 2021 Fed funds rate.

the US Treasury market is no longer a market. It is completely fake. The Federal reserve purchased a larger amount of treasuries in 2020 than the total amount of treasuries newly issued by the US Treasury. This means the "market" on net did not buy any US debt in 2020 but on net sold a little bit. another way of looking at this is that the US government cannot afford to pay a market rate of interest on the national debt which has grown way too large to handle. the US government has made it clear it has no intentions of balancing the budget or paying down US debt. all debt in 2020 was covered by simply printing money which is inflationary and inflation is already rising. The US dollar showed considerable weakness in December 2020.  I noticed that right now the 30-year Treasury amount of 1.67 is just barely above CPI inflation of 1.6. it is pretty unrealistic to be selling 30-year debt at an amount below the current rate of inflation. Since I expect inflation to rise over the next 12 months I expect 30-year US Treasury percentages to rise as well, however, since the market is almost completely artificial and the Federal reserve can push it down as low as they wish it is hard to know. Keep in mind that the Federal reserve has a target rate of inflation of 2% and has been talking that they would allow inflation to go higher than 2%, which I have taken as acknowledgment that the inflation is going to rise and they can do nothing about it. All the US government knows how to do is spend. They are going to continue to pass emergency stimulus bills which will be funded by simply issuing new debt covered by spending money. we have slowly reached a point where more and more of the newly issued US debt has to be covered by the fed, and I think we will see increasing amounts of treasuries being sold on the market as China and Japan and Russia try to unload their existing portfolios. The Federal reserve is quickly becoming the only buyer.  Really anything could happen with this market but they have long abandoned any pretense of normalcy or logic so I don't see any reason why they wouldn't just continue to print money to cover anything that is sold, therefore keeping the rate low.

If you think its going over 2.5 then you are an inflation hawk. You support the theory that the world is awash in money and stimulus and inflation is going to just go on a tear. Me, I support the idea of the Japanification of the economy and no matter how much money and stimulus the US and China dump into the world inflation is just not going to show up. So I believe the rates will be below 2.0.
